sect2.title: Checking Direct Rendering Infrastructure (DRI) Installation
sect2.para: DRI is a framework for allowing software to access graphics hardware in a safe and efficient manner. It is installed in X by default if you have a supported video card. To check if DRI is installed properly, check the log file /var/log/XFree86.0.log or /var/log/Xorg.0.log for statements like:
From an xterm, run glxinfo and look for the phrase:

You can also run the test program glxgears. This program brings up a window with three gears turning. The xterm will display how many frames were drawn every five seconds so this is a reasonable benchmark. The window is scalable, and the frames drawn per second is highly dependent on the size of the window.

sect2.title: Adding TrueType fonts to X
sect2.para: TrueType font support is built into X. The following items need to be completed to make the fonts available.

listitem.para: Establish a directory for the fonts and move any TrueType fonts you want into that directory.
Create the fonts.scale and fonts.dir files in the TrueType font directory.
Ensure the TrueType module is loaded in the XF86Config or xorg.conf.
Ensure the FontPath in XF86Config or Xorg.conf contains the TrueType font directory.

sect3.title: Establish a TrueType font directory
sect3.para: The build of X as given above automatically creates a TrueType font directory: /usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/TTF. This directory already has some TrueType fonts and is set up correctly. If this directory is satisfactory, copy any other TrueType fonts you want into that directory. If not, create a new directory, preferably in the /usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/ directory and put your TrueType fonts there.

sect3.title: Create fonts.scale and fonts.dir
sect3.para: Now change to the directory where you have your TrueType fonts and run mkfontscale && mkfontdir

sect3.title: Ensure TrueType is loaded in XF86Config or xorg.conf
sect3.para: The "Module" section should look like: Section "Module" ... Load "freetype" ... EndSection

sect3.title: Ensure the FontPath in XF86Config points to the TrueType font directory
sect3.para: The "Files" section should look like Section "Files" ... FontPath "/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/[TrueTypeDir]/" ... EndSection

X will now be able to use TrueType fonts when it is restarted. You can check to see if the new fonts are available with the xlsfonts or xfontsel program.

note.para: You should re-run mkfontscale and mkfontdir any time you add or delete TrueType fonts. You should also rerun fc-cache each time you add or remove any fonts.

sect2.title: Setting up keyboards
sect2.para: In this version of X, it has been reported that non-Latin keyboard layouts do not include Latin configurations as was previous practice. To set up a keyboard for Latin and non-Latin input, change the XkbLayout keyboard driver option in the InputDevice section of the XF86Config or xorg.conf file. For example:
sect2.screen: Section "InputDevice" Identifier "Keyboard0" Driver "Keyboard" Option "XkbModel" "pc105" Option "XkbLayout" "en_US,ru" Option "XkbOptions" "grp:switch,grp:alt_shift_toggle,grp_led:scroll" EndSection
sect2.para: In this example, you can use the Alt-Shift combination to switch between keyboard layouts and use the Scroll Lock LED to indicate when the second layout is active.

sect2.title: Setting up XDM
sect2.para: xdm provides a graphical logon capability and is normally set up in /etc/inittab. Most of the information you need to customize xdm is found in its man page. To execute xdm during bootup, change the initdefault level to 5 and add the following lines to /etc/inittab:

screen.userinput: # Run xdm as a separate service x:5:respawn:/usr/X11R6/bin/xdm -nodaemon

sect2.title: Using X Resources
sect2.para: There are many options that can be set in X and X clients via resources. Typically resources are set in the ~/.Xresources file.

A tight binding indicates that the components on either side of the dot must be directly next to each other as defined in a specific implementation.
